1. Standard Binary Search

Find an exact element in a sorted array.

🔧 Adjustments

If midVal < target: low = mid + 1

If midVal > target: high = mid - 1

✅ Use When:

You need to check if an element exists in a sorted array.

🧠 Java Code

int binarySearch(int[] arr, int target) {
    int low = 0, high = arr.length - 1;
    while (low <= high) {
        int mid = low + (high - low) / 2;
        if (arr[mid] == target) return mid;
        else if (arr[mid] < target) low = mid + 1;
        else high = mid - 1;
    }
    return -1; // not found
}

🧭 2. Lower Bound (First Element ≥ Target)

🔧 Adjustments

If arr[mid] < target: low = mid + 1

Else: high = mid - 1

✅ Use When:

You need the first element ≥ target (e.g., start of range).

🧠 Java Code

int lowerBound(int[] arr, int target) {
    int low = 0, high = arr.length - 1, ans = arr.length;
    while (low <= high) {
        int mid = low + (high - low) / 2;
        if (arr[mid] >= target) {
            ans = mid;
            high = mid - 1;
        } else {
            low = mid + 1;
        }
    }
    return ans;
}

⛳ 3. Upper Bound (First Element > Target)

🔧 Adjustments

If arr[mid] <= target: low = mid + 1

Else: high = mid - 1

✅ Use When:

You want to find the first element greater than the target.

🧠 Java Code

int upperBound(int[] arr, int target) {
    int low = 0, high = arr.length - 1, ans = arr.length;
    while (low <= high) {
        int mid = low + (high - low) / 2;
        if (arr[mid] > target) {
            ans = mid;
            high = mid - 1;
        } else {
            low = mid + 1;
        }
    }
    return ans;
}

🔁 4. Find First Occurrence of Duplicate Element

🔧 Adjustments

If arr[mid] == target: update ans = mid and search left (high = mid - 1)

Else standard binary search logic.

✅ Use When:

Duplicates exist, and you want the first index of the target.

🧠 Java Code

int firstOccurrence(int[] arr, int target) {
    int low = 0, high = arr.length - 1, ans = -1;
    while (low <= high) {
        int mid = low + (high - low) / 2;
        if (arr[mid] == target) {
            ans = mid;
            high = mid - 1;
        } else if (arr[mid] < target) {
            low = mid + 1;
        } else {
            high = mid - 1;
        }
    }
    return ans;
}

🧮 5. Find Last Occurrence of Duplicate Element

🔧 Adjustments

If arr[mid] == target: update ans = mid and search right (low = mid + 1)

Else standard binary search logic.

✅ Use When:

Duplicates exist, and you want the last index of the target.

🧠 Java Code

int lastOccurrence(int[] arr, int target) {
    int low = 0, high = arr.length - 1, ans = -1;
    while (low <= high) {
        int mid = low + (high - low) / 2;
        if (arr[mid] == target) {
            ans = mid;
            low = mid + 1;
        } else if (arr[mid] < target) {
            low = mid + 1;
        } else {
            high = mid - 1;
        }
    }
   
    return ans;
}

🎯 Summary Table

Binary Search Variants Cheat Sheet

This table summarizes the most common binary search patterns, what conditions to check, how to adjust the search space, and what each variant is used for.

Variant Condition at mid Adjust low or high Goal
Exact Match arr[mid] == target low = mid + 1 or high = mid - 1 Find element index
Lower Bound arr[mid] >= target high = mid - 1 First ≥ target
Upper Bound arr[mid] > target high = mid - 1 First > target
First Occurrence arr[mid] == target high = mid - 1 Leftmost match
Last Occurrence arr[mid] == target low = mid + 1 Rightmost match

Notes

  • Lower Bound: Useful for finding where an element can be inserted without breaking the sort order.
  • Upper Bound: Helps in range queries, e.g., count of elements equal to a value.
  • These patterns assume the array is sorted in ascending order.

Let me know if you want binary search on rotated sorted arrays, peak elements, or 2D matrices next.

You said: whats lower bound upper cound meaning

ChatGPT said: Great question!

📌 Lower Bound and Upper Bound are binary search variants used to find the position (not necessarily the exact match) of elements in a sorted array. 🔽 Lower Bound ❓ What it means: The index of the first element that is greater than or equal to the target.

✅ Use when: You want to find the starting point of a range, or check how many elements are less than the target.

🔍 Example: java Copy Edit int[] arr = {2, 4, 4, 4, 6, 8}; int target = 4;

// Lower bound of 4 is index 1 (first 4) 🔼 Upper Bound ❓ What it means: The index of the first element that is strictly greater than the target.

✅ Use when: You want to find the ending point of a range, or count how many elements are less than or equal to the target.

🔍 Example: java Copy Edit int[] arr = {2, 4, 4, 4, 6, 8}; int target = 4;

// Upper bound of 4 is index 4 (first element > 4, which is 6) 🔁 Real-world Use Case: Say you’re counting how many times target = 4 appears:

java Copy Edit count = upperBound(arr, 4) - lowerBound(arr, 4); // = 4 - 1 = 3 🧠 Visualization: For arr = {2, 4, 4, 4, 6, 8} and target = 4:

makefile Copy Edit Indexes: 0 1 2 3 4 5 Values: 2 4 4 4 6 8 ↑ ↑ LB=1 UB=4
